CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 10 - Freedom of expression -{General} (Article 10-1 - Freedom of expression);Pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE published on its first page the title of an article due to appear in a future issue together with a summary of the article . The title of the summary was “ The red millionaires ” and it was accompanied by a big picture of the leader of ORG parliamentary group , PERSON , wearing a top hat .
CARDINAL . The summary read as follows :
“ The NORP want to sell off piece - meal the PERSON canned food plant

The PERSON plant is the only undertaking in the region which is still alive . The rest of the plants have been sold off piece - meal . Since the NORP came to power , a campaign to liquidate this plant has commenced . Certain members of ORG wish to dismantle it and sell it off piece - meal . Sources from the plant told our newspaper that the member of ORG , who is responsible for PERSON , with the support of the main creditors ... is behind this dirty affair . Having great influence and parliamentary immunity , he wants to fill his pockets following the sale of the plant .

At present the plant is not operating and is making substantial losses , and this situation is being used to maximum advantage by this MP . Since the plant is not operating and is not profitable , the shareholders want to liquidate it . The problem is that the plant could operate if the shareholders did not hinder the plant 's staff .
( A detailed article about this affair will be published in the DATE issue on page CARDINAL ) ” .
CARDINAL . DATE , on DATE , Mr ORG brought civil defamation proceedings against the newspaper and against the author of the article . He argued , inter alia , that :
“ ... the defendants disseminated information which is defamatory of me as a citizen , an MP and as the leader of ORG parliamentary group ...

... the article , which is accompanied by my picture , contains the following defamatory statements : ' The NORP want to sell the PERSON canned food plant off piece - meal ' ... ' Since the NORP came to power , a campaign to liquidate this plant has commenced . Certain members of ORG wish to dismantle it and sell it off piece - meal ' .

By publishing this article , the defendants , acted in bad faith , misinforming public opinion about my actions in my capacity as MP and also about the activity of the ORG parliamentary group which I represent , accusing us of destroying an enterprise which is part of the national economy . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE Flux published the article announced in its CARDINAL DATE issue . The article was based on the account of ORG , the deputy Chief Executive Officer of the PERSON canned food plant , and reported on events concerning alleged attempts by a NORP parliamentarian ( PERSON ) , to have the plant declared bankrupt and sold off . It stated , inter alia , that the parliamentarian had made use of ORG and other ORG bodies for that purpose and that he ( PERSON ) had told ORG that his actions were supported by the ORG parliamentary group . According to ORG , CARDINAL other plants from the region had already been declared bankrupt and sold off in the same manner .
CARDINAL . On DATE Judge GPE , who was also President of ORG , ruled in favour of Mr Stepaniuc , relying on the following grounds :

“ From the content and meaning of the article [ of DATE ] it is clear that ORG and the author made defamatory and false accusations against Mr ORG , in particular to the effect that he , in his capacity as MP and leader of the ORG parliamentary group , had engaged in actions directed at destroying enterprises within the national economy of GPE for personal gain .
In addition , the article was accompanied by a picture of the plaintiff .
The defendants did not present in the article any proof of the truthfulness of their accusations .

In such circumstances , the court considers it necessary to note that any article should be sincere , correct and contain only truthful revelations which correspond to reality and are not based on rumours , anonymous letters or inadequately checked information from unreliable sources .
The defendants , however , did not abide by common sense and unjustly defamed the plaintiff .
Accordingly , the defendants clearly overstepped the limits of constructive criticism of public persons necessary in a NORP society .

In the court 's view , the fact that the plaintiff 's name was not given in the article is not conclusive , since his picture and the meaning and content of the article make it clear that it is directed against him . Consequently , he was exposed to mental and moral suffering which should be remedied by the defendants .

In establishing the compensation to be paid for non - pecuniary damage , the court shall take into consideration the considerable vehemence of the attack against PERSON , the large readership of the newspaper and the degree of suffering endured by the plaintiff .

The court should also take into consideration the public functions occupied by Mr Stepaniuc , that of MP and leader of a parliamentary group , which should increase the award for moral damage . Therefore the court considers it necessary to award the plaintiff the maximum amount of compensation provided for by the law . ”

CARDINAL . The court found the statement : “ The NORP want to sell the PERSON canned food plant off piece - meal ” to be defamatory and ordered the newspaper and the author to pay the plaintiff CARDINAL Moldovan Lei ( MDL ) ( the equivalent of QUANTITY ( ORG ) at the time ) and MDL CARDINAL respectively . It further ordered the newspaper to issue an apology within DATE . The defendants were also ordered to pay the court fees .

CARDINAL . NORP The newspaper lodged an appeal against the judgment in which it argued , inter alia , that the article had been directed against GPE , another MP from the ORG parliamentary group and not against Mr ORG . The latter 's picture had been published in order to make it easy to identify the ORG parliamentary group , since he was its President .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant also argued that the impugned article was only an abstract of an article to be published subsequently and that the statement found by the first - instance court to be defamatory was merely a subjective conclusion drawn by the author based on the information published in the main article . The applicant further submitted that ORG had also instituted defamation proceedings against the newspaper and requested that the CARDINAL actions instituted by Mr Stepaniuc and by ORG be joined and examined together .

CARDINAL . The applicant finally argued that Judge PERSON lacked independence and impartiality because he was a friend of Mr ORG and had been appointed President of ORG by the ORG parliamentary group . The majority of the defamation cases between PERSON and Mr Stepaniuc were examined by him personally and his decisions were stereotyped . In other defamation cases between LOC and representatives of the Government , Judge PERSON had always ruled in favour of the latter and had awarded them the maximum amount provided for by law .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the appeal as being unfounded . It did not take into consideration the article published on DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The newspaper lodged an appeal on points of law , relying on the same grounds as in its appeal and added , inter alia , that the impugned article merely reproduced the opinion of the management of the PERSON canned food plant .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal . It stated , inter alia , that it was clear that the information published in the article about Mr Stepaniuc did not correspond to reality ; moreover , his picture had been attached to the article .
CARDINAL . It appears that the defamation action brought by ORG was struck out due to ORG 's failure to appear before the court .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW in force at the material time read :
Article CARDINAL . Protection of honour and dignity

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any natural or legal person shall be entitled to apply to the courts to seek the withdrawal of statements which are damaging to his or her honour and dignity and do not correspond to reality , as well as statements which are not damaging to honour and dignity , but do not correspond to reality .

( CARDINAL ) When the media body which circulated such statements is not capable of proving that these statements correspond to reality , the court shall compel the publishing office of the media body to publish , not later then DATE after the entry into force of the judicial decision , a withdrawal of the statements in the same column , on the same page or in the same programme or series of broadcasts . ”
LAW Compensation for moral damage

“ ( CARDINAL ) The moral damage caused to a person as a result of circulation through the mass media or by organisations or persons of statements which do not correspond to reality , as well as statements concerning his or her private or family life , without his or her consent , shall be compensated by way of a pecuniary award . The amount of the award shall be determined by the court .

( CARDINAL ) The amount of the award shall be determined by the court in each case as an amount equal to DATE minimum wages if the information has been circulated by a legal person and DATE minimum wages if the information has been circulated by a natural person . ”
CARDINAL . The Freedom House Organisation DATE country report for GPE , insofar as relevant , reads as follows :

“ ... In DATE , the principle of the rule of law was under challenge in GPE . This was evidenced by the rising number of cases filed by NORP citizens in ORG and actions taken by the ORG and government to suppress judicial independence . Also affecting the fragile balance of power among the legislative , executive , and judicial branches of government in DATE were a series of judicial nominations based on loyalty to the ruling party , the dismissal of the ombudsman , and attempts to limit the independence of ORG .

In DATE , ORG ( MAJ ) signaled that the government had started a process of “ mass cleansing ” in the judicial sector . CARDINAL judges lost their jobs , including PERSON , a member of the court of appeals , and PERSON , the chairman of ORG . In the case of PERSON , the move was likely revenge for decisions by the court of appeals that favored ORG and local oil importers over the government .

The situation worsened when President PERSON refused to prolong the mandates of CARDINAL other judges . The ORG conveyed a statement on the matter to ORG rapporteurs who were in GPE at the time on a fact - finding mission . The government instructed ORG to delay court decisions related to the payment of material damages by state institutions . In DATE , PERSON , chairman of ORG , stated at a press conference that senior government officials were pressuring judges to issue rulings that favored government bodies .

In DATE , President PERSON promulgated a constitutional amendment giving him the right to appoint judges . Under the amendment , the head of state will appoint the chairs of courts , their deputies , and lower - ranking judges for DATE terms at the recommendation of ORG . ORG will appoint for DATE terms members of ORG , including the chief of ORG , the prosecutor - general , and the minister of justice . These changes provide evidence that the country 's NORP leaders are weakening judicial independence and subordinating this branch of governance to their authority ... ”
CARDINAL . ORG DATE country report on GPE read as follows in its relevant parts :
“ ... The LAW provides for an independent judiciary ; however , official pressure and corruption of judges remained a problem .
There continued to be credible reports that local prosecutors and judges extorted bribes for reducing charges or sentences .

Following a major reorganization in DATE , the judiciary consists of CARDINAL levels : lower courts , courts of appeals , and ORG . A separate ORG has exclusive authority in cases regarding the constitutionality of draft and final legislation , decrees , and other government acts . While ORG was generally regarded as fair and objective , observers frequently charged that other courts were corrupt or politically influenced .

The LAW authorizes the President , acting on the nomination of ORG , to appoint judges for an initial period of DATE . Before being reappointed , judges must undertake specialized judicial training and pass a test evaluated by ORG . Political factors have played a large role in the reappointment of judges . ”
